pros:
Flexible Dressing

Initiative to Work-life Balance with 2 hours of early release every Friday

Willing to experiment

The majority of the old-timers in the airline industry are good folks and genuinely enjoy their work despite the industry's environment.

Hybrid work environment - typically 1 or 2 days' work from home.
cons:
Typical of a large local company and a GLC; promotes pseudo-flexibility and a false sense of work-life balance. This may be an industry thing, but do not mistake this to only apply to operations - the team is severely under-staffed across all departments and this is largely due to misplaced headcount in the organisation.

Ways of promotion are questionable and opportunities within the organisation are limited and again, questionable. Things happen for certain people in both directions; up and being stagnant.

Things are expected to move day-in and day-out, but you'd always be instructed to move - often without being communicated to the whys. The middle management are at times unaware as well. Rank & Files typically get their questions deflected or largely ignored.

The organisation is moving in multiple directions - much like throwing a large net in hopes of getting something right. Feasible for organisation with a deep pocket at their discretion and enough quality manpower, but this makes you wonder - is Scoot being purposeful in the utilisation of the workforce or is it simply a management game of "producing work" and "results".

Covid measures relaxed and aviation are bouncing back due to demand - hiring is on the rise. So is the turnover rate, which is a lot faster than they can hire.

A 10-year-old company that constantly experiments and tries new things which are good. However, their foundation is too weak; technology, business processes, knowledge base etc. to engage in these activities at this point of time.

The physical environment is very poor - don't let the Changi Airport image fool you. The office has no windows as it's located in the basement. The pantry is severely lacking without amenities - food, drinks and even disposable items.

The laptops issued are not conducive for work - the battery runs out within 1.5 hours and there's a lack of charging ports in the meeting room (if you're lucky to get one to begin with). The IT around the office in general is very lacking; projectors, telecommunication devices, sockets are not functioning.

Good job if you want to try flying but not a career option.

pros: A fun place to do many things and learn many things
cons:
You may do many things but be aware that what you do may not add value to grow you as a professional. You may learn many things but be aware that you may not be learning the right or best practice way of doing things, some may even be borderline illegal.

It's better to join as an experienced hire than a fresh graduate where you contribute to grow the company which gives a sense of achievement. Unfortunately due to the low bar of entry for those who join in the 1-2 years of the startup, many of these folks were too quickly promoted before acquiring sufficient experience, maturity or developed appropriate managerial behaviors. This results in frustration by experienced lateral hires who later join the coy and report into them  - the funny thing is the lateral hires are often more skilled, more experienced, better mannered and cost lesser than these managers whom they have to report into, and can do the job of the middle-managers and much better too.

The inexperienced middle managers remain in the coy simply because they have been with the coy during the startup years, however top management needs to realize this mentality cannot be allowed any longer if they want to let the coy grow. These middle managers value to the coy is actually diminishing as the company transforms to a larger setup where profiles with better background and experience are needed to take the coy to the next stage.  Some of these middle managers get very arrogant because they have become 'untouchables' due to the immunity given to them by top management, consciously or unconsciously. 

The result is talented experience staff leave and the coy is stuck in a vicious cycle of hiring lower quality talents that can be 'subdued' by the arrogant inexperienced middle managers as they fear hiring people who are better than them.

review_title: So much politics, Feels like Startup company, No process
pros:
* Travel Benefits (Staff travel is so cheap!)
* Great office location
* Lots of events, trainings, there is free udemy access.
* Good annual bonus (before covid happened)
* Flexible working hours
* The office is very very nice, and decorated nicely though it doesn't have a window. It's a big office without any windows.
cons:
Politics tons of it.
The departments are all working in their own tribes. It will feel like you are working with other companies even though you work in the same office. There is no integration between departments. Each has their own agenda, and they push whatever agenda they have on a different department. It will depend on how close you are to the department head to get your objective going.
There is no process, no priotization, everything is urgent. It feels like a startup company where you work on whoever is the most important. You need to know the specific people so you can get something going. You need to be buddy buddy with them.
There are managers, but there is no accountability. Even as a manager, if something erupts it is the subordinate's fault even though the manager approved it. Manager will not be there to manage, they will just listen and note what's happening. They're like ghost employees. 
There are also skeleton employees who get away without doing anything in other departments, and there are employees with no clear roles who do almost everything and are very overworked because the manager not doing their job.
If you don't pleasethe manager from other departments or they just don't like you as a person, you will not have power here. Some managers are very old school, and immature they will actually scold, throw tantrum and act mad just to push an objective that does not make sense instead of being understanding and mature.

Most people are rude. There is no culture of helpfulness and respect.
It surprises me that vendors have better processes and are more level-headed than people who work here.

pros:
1. Cheap staff travel ticket. You can purchase staff travel as much as you like for you and 5 other nominees. 
2. You can have any kind of hairstyle and color just don’t be outrageous. 
3. Training is shorter compared to other airlines.
4. You get to meet and work with different people almost every flight. 
5. People expect lesser from you as you are working for a LCC.
cons:
1. Staff travel is on standby basis. You can book and make payment for you flight but if your flight happens to be full, you won’t fly. 
2. Half of the crew in charge and seniors are always looking down on new crews and always tend to zap them instead of helping them to learn. 
3. You will have to share a room with another same gender crew during layover unless you are lucky. 
4. Low salary even after all the allowances. They pay you a mere $30+  for transport allowance for layover flights and that is for your to and fro to the airport. If you land or depart when there is still public transport, you don’t get your transport allowance. 
5. Standbys are horrible. You get Atleast one or two standbys a month and it starts from 0000hrs to 2359hrs. If you take mc, you’ll be on standby the next day at 1200hrs. 
6. You pay for almost everything yourself from luggages to shoes to even your food. You can purchase on board snacks or meals at only 50% off. They don’t even provide meals. 
7. Get ready to have flights Everyday for turnarounds. There are flights that make you report at 8am and you report off at 11am, wasting your travel time. The roster will state 8am reporting time but you’ll have to reach Atleast 30-45 mins before that or you’ll be reprimanded by your in charge for the flight. Nobody reports on time.

pros: - You get to visit different countries (although mostly china)
cons:
- A lot of drama happens on board if you get a terrible set of crew/ crew-in-charge. Many people join scoot after being deterred by the political lifestyle in SQ, but i’d say there’s good crew & bad crews & if you get bad crews who enjoys stirring things then you’ll operate a long-ass flight feeling like throwing yourself off the flight.
- Crazy flight hours, little rest. There’s a regulation as to how much rest is needed before your next flight, and the company would take advantage of whatever they can. You fly 13hrs to Berlin, rest 24hrs (not even fully 24hrs because after disembarking pax, doing your routined checks, immigration & travelling to hotel etc, you’re probably left with only about 21hrs) & fly back the next day for another 13hrs. You’re 26hrs on flight and 24hrs on ground to “rest”—with a time difference of 5hrs & drastic temperature change during winter—all because the company wants to maximise profits. We operate 5hrs to Perth & 5hrs back to Singapore with a 1 hr transit time, Perth used to be a layover destination but got too expensive & they want to cut cost, so the crews suffers. 
- Oh, and no you can’t be sick, because if you fall sick even once a month, you’d be reviewed & deemed as unfit to fly. and no, you can’t go to flight if you’re really sick, you’d be sent home & issued demerit points. Or if you’re allowed to fly (with your crew-in-charge closing one eye), you’d either be scolded by the pax for “passing the virus” or your senior crews for being “irresponsible & a threat to their safety”
- High human turnover—a new batch of crews comes in once every two weeks approximately.

I strongly agree with two of the previous reviews:

“So much politics. Boss don't like you then you are doomed. Always got favourite pet. Treat you like dirt. Some departments worse than others.”

“Unfair treatment especially by management towards staff that are deemed outside their clique. Top management turned a total blind eye to the unfair treatment and even condone it.”

This really depends on which department you are in, there are nice departments, but for my deprtment, unfortunately this was the case.

Co-workers form cliques and new staff who join are not welcomed in the clique, especially if your personality is deemed as “different” from the rest.

Co-workers will then start creating politics about you within the team and then to your manager and eventually the upper management, to the extent where the upper management will turn sour on you as well and start driving you to resign on your own (micromanaging, humiliating you unnecessarily in front of department meetings, ignoring you when you need their help, taking away your responsibilities, joining the office bullies, finding fault with your work even if you are performing fine, and so on). All of this happened in my case.

Have tried to speak to my upper management on this issue but my feedback was ignored and immediately shot down.
